section.title: The Actionmenu
section.para: From the Actionsmenu you can access your Preferencesand configure Servers. If your enthusiasm for GêBR has lead you to read the whole manual, you have probably used almost all available features found in these options. But just in case, below you will find the documentation for these options.

section.title: Preferences
section.para: The details you provide in the Preferencesdialog box will be adopted as the default by GêBR. Specifically:

listitem.para: User name:will be used as the default for Author:when you create Projects, Lines and Flows.
Email:will be used as the default for Email:when you create Projects, Lines and Flows.
User's menus directory:will be the default directory where GêBR's Menusare maintained ( mnufiles).

mediaobject.caption: Preferences menu opens a dialog box where you edit the user name, email, menu's directory and the HTML editor.

section.para: Advanced settings in Preferences menu expands the dialog box where you edit the maestro server and HTML editor.

listitem.para: Maestro Server: will be the default for Maestro Server when you start GêBR, the localhost is the default for Maestro Server when you connect GêBR for the first time.
HTML editor: the default text editor that GêBR will open when creating reports on Projects, Lines and Flows.

section.title: Servers configuration
section.para: GêBR can take benefit of the resources of multiple machines. To handle it, GêBR is segmented in three layers:

itemizedlist.listitem: The host machine (GêBR-client), from where the user sends requests
An intermediate layer (GêBR-maestro), where all the jobs are coordinated
Executors (GêBR-daemons), where the jobs are executed

section.para: The user can be connected to one maestro at once. Each maestro, in turn, can be connected to many daemons. To ease the task of handling of files by the maestro, one requirement is that all the daemons must be in the same Network File System (NFS).

The Servers Interface has three parts:
Maestro entry- central unit of coordination of multiple machines
Servers configuration - choose the daemons associated to the current maestro
Groups configuration- configure the groups of daemons on the current maestro

section.title: Maestro Entry
Servers configuration
section.para: Once selected a coordinator machine (maestro), the user can associate machines to that maestro.

The lines represent the machines associated to the maestro. Each line has two columns: the first column shows if the option Auto-connect is activated or not; the second column shows the name (hostname) of the machine. The user can add a new machine by clicking over New and entering the name of address of the machine.

section.title: Groups configuration
section.para: The user can use just a couple of the machines associated to the maestro. Using different subsets of machines can be managed through the creation of groups of machines.
In the bottom part of the Servers interface, the user can create/edit daemons groups. The functionality is through mouse Drag and Drop.
To create a group, the user needs to click over a server in the list and drag it to the + icon. A text box is going to be prompted for the name of the group. Groups with same names are not accepted.

section.title: The execution log
section.para: GêBR remembers most of the users actions, as well as the results of these actions, in the so called execution log. This log is shown at the bottom of the main window, which can be presented in the collapsed form (default) or the expanded form like the window below.

mediaobject.caption: At the bottom of GêBR's main window you will find the execution log, which displays information on all of GêBR processes.

tip.para:
In
Actions Preferences at the bottom of the dialog box, we can see the box Load past-execution log. By checking this box we choose to exhibit the whole log, including actions from past dates. By leaving the box unchecked we choose to have a compact log, which only shows actions that have taken place since GêBR's last initialization.
